title: 114_hr4308
content: The Act is titled the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Act." It defines terms like "Commission" and "Museum" and establishes the Commission for this purpose. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture is established with 8 members appointed by various leaders. Members must have a commitment to Asian Pacific American history, art, and culture. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture requires members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, teaching Asian Pacific American history, public service, museum administration, planning, design, and construction. The Commission requires members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, teaching Asian Pacific American history, public service, planning, design, or construction of museum facilities. Federal employees are prohibited from serving on the Commission. Initial members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson is selected by majority vote of all members. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 4 of the Act. The Commission is required to submit reports to the President and Congress regarding recommendations for establishing a National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture in Washington, DC. The reports will address issues such as collection availability, cost, impact on regional museums, potential locations, and whether the Museum should be part of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission is tasked with developing a fundraising plan to support the establishment, operation, and maintenance of the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture. The plan will consider best practices for engaging the community, governance structure, and cost implications. The reports must be submitted within 18 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission is required to develop a plan for funding the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture without relying on Federal funds. An independent review of the plan's viability must be conducted, and the plan and review submitted to specific committees. The Commission is tasked with developing a funding plan for the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture without Federal funds. Recommendations for a legislative plan of action to establish and construct the Museum will be submitted to relevant committees. A national conference must be held within 18 months of the Commission's initial members being appointed. The Commission may convene a national conference comprised of individuals dedicated to the advancement of Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. The Commission may convene a national conference comprised of individuals dedicated to the advancement of Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission may employ an executive director and necessary personnel, with pay rates consistent with temporary organization employees. Individuals employed are not considered Federal employees. Federal agencies may provide technical assistance upon request, but no Federal employees can be detailed. No Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission members serve without pay and can receive travel expenses. The Commission can accept gifts to aid its work and is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting final reports. It is responsible for funding itself through contributions and cannot use federal funds.
